André the Giant<ref name{{convert|7|ft|4|in|m}}<ref name{{convert|550|lb|kg}}<ref name{{birth date|1946|5|19}}<ref name[[Grenoble]], France<ref name{{death date and age|1993|01|27|1946|5|19}} [[Paris, France]] Congestive heart failure "[[Grenoble]] in the [[French Alps]]" Frank Valois<ref name1963 1992 Andr Ren Roussimoff(May 19, 1946 January 27, 1993),cite webhttp://www.onlineworldofwrestling.com/profiles/a/andre-the-giant.htmlAndré the Giant ProfileSeptember 22, 2008Online World of Wrestlinghttp://web.archive.org/web/20080921232831/http://www.onlineworldofwrestling.com/profiles/a/andre-the-giant.htmlSeptember 21, 2008nocite webAndré the GiantIMDbhttp://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000764/March 13, 2009http://web.archive.org/web/20090127063647/http://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000764/January 27, 2009nobest known asAndr the Giant, was a Frenchprofessional wrestlingprofessional wrestlerandactor. He most famously feuded withHulk Hogan, culminating atWrestleMania III, and his best-remembered film role was that of Fezzik, the giant inThe Princess Bride (film)The Princess Bride.His size was a result ofgigantismcaused by excess growth hormone, which later resulted inacromegaly. It also led to him being called "TheEighth Wonder of the World".cite webAndre the Giant: BioWWEhttp://www.wwe.com/superstars/halloffame/inductees/andrethegiantApril 2, 2011http://web.archive.org/web/20090501202657/http://www.wwe.com/superstars/halloffame/andrethegiant/bio/May 1, 2009cite webhttp://www.andrethegiant.com/André the Giant official websiteJuly 8, 2007http://web.archive.org/web/20070704022027/http://www.andrethegiant.com/July 4, 2007no

In the World Wrestling Federation (WWF, now known asWWE), Andr was aList of WWE World Heavyweight Championsone-time WWFWWE World Heavyweight Championshipchampioncite webhttp://www.wwe.com/inside/titlehistory/wwechampionship/304454122Andre the Giant's first reign[[WWE]]February 15, 2011and aList of World Tag Team Champions (WWE)one-time WWFWorld Tag Team Championship (WWE)tag team champion.cite webhttp://www.wwe.com/inside/titlehistory/worldtagteam/3044541321111121Andre the Giant and Haku's first reign[[WWE]]February 15, 2011In 1993, Andr was the inaugural inductee into theWWE Hall of FameWWF Hall of Fame.cite webAndre the Giant: BioWWEhttp://www.wwe.com/superstars/halloffame/inductees/andrethegiantApril 2, 2011cite bookWWE LegendsSolomonBrian68–71[[Pocket Books]]20060-7434-9033-9
article.heading: Early life
article.paragraph: Andr Roussimoff was born inGrenoble, France, to Boris and Mariann Roussimoff, a couple ofBulgarianandPolandPolishancestry.cite bookLapradePatHebertBertrandMad Dogs, Midgets and Screw Jobs: The Untold Story of How Montreal Shaped the World of Wrestlinghttp://books.google.com/books?idFebruary 1, 2013ECW Press978-1-77090-296-11910cite bookHornbakerTimLegends of Pro Wrestling: 150 Years of Headlocks, Body Slams, and Piledrivershttp://books.google.com/books?idJuly 3, 2012Skyhorse Publishing Company, Inc.978-1-61321-314-8413His nickname growing up was "Dd". As a child, he displayed symptoms of hisgigantismvery early, reaching a height of 6'3" (190.5 cm) and a weight ofconvert240lbby the age of 12. PlaywrightSamuel Beckett, a neighbor who later won the Nobel Prize for Literature,cite webhttps://web.archive.org/web/20120420001825/http://historicalmeetups.com/post/1524567373/samuel-beckett-playwright-novelist-and-nobelApril 20, 2012http://historicalmeetups.com/post/1524567373/samuel-beckett-playwright-novelist-and-nobelSamuel Beckett Playwright, novelist, and NobelHistorical Meet-UpsJune 8, 2012bought some land in 1953 near a hamlet around forty miles northeast of Paris. He built a cottage for himself with the help of Andr's father Boris Rousimoff. When Beckett found out that Rousimoff was having trouble getting his son to school, Beckett offered to drive Andr to school in his truck, as he did not fit on the bus. When Andr recounted the drives with Beckett, he revealed that they rarely talked about anything other than cricket.Cite webhttp://www.themarysue.com/samuel-beckett-andre-the-giant/Samuel Beckett Used to Drive André the Giant to School, All They Talked About Was CricketJuly 11, 2011January 9, 2015The Mary SueThe Mary Sue

Roussimoff was a good student, particularly inmathematics, but he dropped out after the eighth grade since he did not think having a high school education was necessary for a farm laborer. He spent years working on his father's farm, where, according to his brother, Jacques, he could perform the work of three men. He also completed anapprenticeshipin woodworking, and next worked in a factory that manufactured engines forbalerhay balers. None of these occupations, however, brought him any satisfaction.cite episodeAndré the GiantBiography[[A&E (TV channel)|A&E Network]]1998-01-13
article.heading: Professional wrestling career
Early career
article.paragraph: At age 17, Roussimoff moved to Paris and was taughtprofessional wrestlingby a local promoter who recognized the earning potential of Roussimoff's size. He trained at night and worked as a mover during the day to pay living expenses.Roussimoff was billed as "Gant Ferr", a name based on the French folk hero:fr:Grand FerrGrand Ferr,and began wrestling in Paris and nearby areas. Canadian promoter and wrestler Frank Valois met Roussimoff in 1966, becoming his business manager and adviser. Roussimoff began making a name for himself wrestling in the United Kingdom, Germany, Australia, New Zealand, and Africa.cite bookAndré the Giant: A Legendary LifeKrugmanMichael4[[Pocket Books]]2009978-1-4165-4112-7cite bookAndré the Giant: A Legendary LifeKrugmanMichael7[[Pocket Books]]2009978-1-4165-4112-7

He made his Japanese debut in 1970, billed as "Monster Roussimoff", wrestling for theInternational Wrestling Enterprise. Wrestling as both a singles and tag team competitor, he quickly was made the company's tag team champion alongside Michael Nador.cite webhttp://www.wrestling-titles.com/japan/iwe/iwe-t.htmlIWA World Tag Team TitleWrestling TitlesFebruary 23, 2011During his time in Japan, doctors first informed Roussimoff that he suffered fromacromegaly.

Roussimoff next moved toMontral, Qubec, where he became an immediate success, regularly selling out theMontreal Forum.cite bookPain and PassionMcCoyHeath96[[ECW Press]]2007978-1-55022-787-1However, promoters eventually ran out of plausible opponents for him and, as the novelty of his size wore off, the gate receipts dwindled.Roussimoff was defeated byAdnan Al-KaissieinBaghdadin 1971,The Sheik of Baghdad: Tales of Celebrity and Terror from Pro Wrestling's General AdnanTriumph Books 2005and wrestled numerous times in 1972 for Verne Gagne'sAmerican Wrestling Association(AWA) as a special attraction until Valois appealed toVince McMahon, Sr.Vince McMahon Sr., founder of theWWEWorld Wide Wrestling Federation(WWWF), for advice.cite bookAndré the Giant: A Legendary LifeKrugmanMichael9[[Pocket Books]]2009978-1-4165-4112-7McMahon suggested several changes. He felt Roussimoff should be portrayed as a large, immovable monster, and to enhance the perception of his size, McMahon discouraged Roussimoff from performing maneuvers such asdropkicks(although he was capable of performing such agile maneuvers before his health deteriorated in later life). He also began billing Roussimoff as "Andr the Giant" and set up a travel-intensive schedule, loaning him to wrestling associations around the world,cite bookDusty: Reflections of an American DreamRhodesDustyDusty Rhodes (wrestler)95–96Sports Publishing LLC2005978-1-58261-907-1cite bookSex, Lies and Headlocks: The Real Story of Vince McMahon and the World Wrestling Federation[[Crown Publishing Group|Crown Publishers]]AssaelShaunMooneyhamMike712002978-0-609-60690-2to keep him from becoming overexposed in any area.Promoters had to guarantee Andr a certain amount of money as well as pay McMahon's WWWF booking fee.cite bookAndré the Giant: A Legendary LifeKrugmanMichael12–13[[Pocket Books]]2009978-1-4165-4112-7
article.heading: World Wide Wrestling Federation and World Wrestling Federation
Undefeated streak (19731987)
article.paragraph: On March 26, 1973, Andr debuted in the World Wide Wrestling Federation (later World Wrestling Federation) as aFace (professional wrestling)fan favorite, defeatingBuddy Wolfein New York'sMadison Square Garden.cite webhttp://www.thehistoryofwwe.com/73.htmWWWF @ New York City, NY – Madison Square Garden – March 26, 1973The History of WWEFebruary 13, 2011

Andr was one of professional wrestling's most beloved "babyfaces" throughout the 1970s and early 1980s. As such,Gorilla Monsoonoften stated that Andr had never been defeated for 15 years by pinfall or submission prior toWrestleMania III; however, Andr had lost in matches outside of the WWF: a pinfall loss in Mexico toCanek (wrestler)Canekin 1984 and a submission loss in Japan toAntonio Inokiin 1986.cite bookAndré the Giant: A Legendary LifeKrugmanMichael110[[Pocket Books]]2009978-1-4165-4112-7cite webhttp://www.puroresucentral.com/inoki.htmlAntonio Inoki: Career HistoryPuroresu CentralFebruary 13, 2011He also had sixty-minute time limit draws with the two other major world champions of the day,Harley RaceandNick Bockwinkel.

In 1976, Andr fought professional boxerChuck Wepnerin an unscripted boxer-versus-wrestler fight. The wild fight was shown via telecast as part of the undercard of theMuhammad Aliversus Antonio Inoki fight and ended when Andr threw Wepner over the top rope and outside the ring.
In 1980, he feuded with Hulk Hogan, wrestling him at Shea Stadium'sShowdown at Sheaand in Pennsylvania. The feud continued in Japan in 1982 and 1983.

In 1982, Vince McMahon, Sr. sold the World Wide Wrestling Federation to his son,Vince McMahonVince McMahon, Jr..cite bookNational Wrestling Alliance: The Untold Story of the Monopoly That Strangled Pro WrestlingHornbakerTim193[[ECW Press]]2007978-1-55022-741-3As McMahon began to expand his newly acquired promotion to the national level, he required his wrestlers to appear exclusively for him. McMahon signed Andr to these terms in 1984, although he still allowed him to work in Japan forNew Japan Pro Wrestling(NJPW).cite bookAndré the Giant: A Legendary LifeKrugmanMichael69–70[[Pocket Books]]2009978-1-4165-4112-7

One of Andr's feuds pitted him against the "Mongolian Giant"Killer Khan. According to the storyline, Khan had snapped Andr's ankle during a match on May 2, 1981, inRochester, New York, by leaping off the top rope and crashing down upon it with his knee-drop.cite bookMain Event: WWE in the Raging 80sShieldsBrian55–58[[Pocket Books]]2006978-1-4165-3257-6In reality, Andr had broken his ankle getting out of bed the morning before the match.cite bookAndré the Giant: A Legendary LifeKrugmanMichael48[[Pocket Books]]2009978-1-4165-4112-7The injury and subsequent rehabilitation was worked into the existing Andr/Khan storyline. After a stay at Beth Israel Hospital in Boston, Andr returned with payback on his mind. The two battled on July 20, 1981, at Madison Square Garden in a match that resulted in aProfessional wrestling#Disqualificationdouble disqualification.cite bookThe History of Professional Wrestling: The Results WWF 1963–1989CawthonGraham339CreateSpace Independent Publishing Platform2013978-1-4928-2597-5Their feud continued as fans filled arenas up and down theEast Coast of the United Stateseast coastto witness their matches. On November 14, 1981, at theSpectrum (arena)Philadelphia Spectrum, Andr decisively defeated Khan in what was billed as a "Mongolian stretcher match", in which the loser must be taken to the dressing room on a stretcher.cite bookAndré the Giant: A Legendary LifeKrugmanMichael48–60[[Pocket Books]]2009978-1-4165-4112-7

File:Andre the Giant.jpgthumbAndr (second from right) feuded withBig John Studd(left) in the build towardsWrestleMania I, and later withKing Kong Bundy(second from left)Another feud involved a man who considered himself to be the "true giant" of wrestling:Big John Studd.Throughout the early to mid-1980s, Andr and Studd fought all over the world, battling to try to determine who the real giant of wrestling was. In 1984, Studd took the feud to a new level when he and partnerKen Pateraknocked out Andr during a televised tag team match and proceeded to cut off Andr's hair.After gaining revenge on Patera, Andr met Studd in a "Professional wrestling throws#Body slambody slamchallenge" at the firstWrestleMania IWrestleMania, held March 31, 1985, at Madison Square Garden in New York City.cite bookBrian ShieldsMain Event: WWE in the Raging 80shttp://books.google.com/books?idJune 15, 2010Simon and Schuster978-1-4516-0467-2150–Andr slammed Studd to win the match and collect theUnited States dollar$15,000 prize, then proceeded to throw cash to the fans before having the bag taken from him by Studd's manager,Bobby HeenanBobby "The Brain" Heenan.cite webhttp://www.wwe.com/shows/wrestlemania/history/wm1/factsstats/WrestleMania I Facts/Stats[[WWE]]February 14, 2011

The following year, atWrestleMania 2, on April 7, 1986, Andr continued to display his dominance by winning a twenty-manBattle royal (professional wrestling)battle royalwhich featured topNational Football Leaguestars and wrestlers.cite webhttp://www.wwe.com/shows/wrestlemania/history/wm2/results/WrestleMania 2 results[[WWE]]February 14, 2011Andr last eliminatedBret Hartto win the contest.cite bookAndré the Giant: A Legendary LifeKrugmanMichael107[[Pocket Books]]2009978-1-4165-4112-7

After WrestleMania 2, Andr continued his feud with Studd andKing Kong Bundy. Around this time, Andr requested a leave of absence to tend to his health—effects from his acromegaly that were beginning to take their toll—as well as tour Japan. He had also gotten a part in the filmThe Princess Bride (film)The Princess Bride. To explain Andr's absence, a storyline was developed in which Heenan—suggesting that Andr was secretly afraid of Studd and Bundy, whom Heenan bragged were unbeatable—challenged Andr and a partner of his choosing to wrestle Studd and Bundy in a televised tag team match. When Andr failed to show, WWF presidentJack Tunneyindefinitely suspended him.cite bookWWE EncyclopediaShieldsBrianSullivanKevin12–13[[Dorling Kindersley|DK]]2009978-0-7566-4190-0Later in the summer of 1986, upon Andr's return to the United States, he began wearing a mask and competing as the "Giant Machine" in a stable known asThe Machines (professional wrestling)the Machines. (Blackjack MulliganBig MachineandBill EadieSuper Machinewere the other members.) The WWF's television announcers sold the Machines—a gimmick that was copied from theNew Japan Pro Wrestlingcharacter "Super Strong Machine", played by Japanese wrestlerJunji Hirata,cite webhttp://www.onlineworldofwrestling.com/profiles/m/machines.htmlThe Machines' ProfileOnline World of WrestlingJuly 8, 2007http://web.archive.org/web/20070621210036/http://www.onlineworldofwrestling.com/profiles/m/machines.htmlJune 21, 2007no—as "a new tag team from Japan" and claimed not to know the identities of the wrestlers, even though it was obvious to fans that it was Andr competing as the Giant Machine. Heenan, Studd, and Bundy complained to Tunney, who eventually told Heenan that if it could be proven that Andr and the Giant Machine were the same person, Andr would be fired. Andr thwarted Heenan, Studd, and Bundy at every turn. Then, in late 1986, the Giant Machine "disappeared," and Andr was reinstated. Foreshadowing Andr's heel turn, Heenan expressed his approval of the reinstatement but did not explain why.
article.heading: Feud with Hulk Hogan (19871988)
article.paragraph: File:Andre and Bobby Heenan.jpgthumbrightAndr was managed byBobby Heenan(seen in front of him) during parts of his feud withHulk HoganAndr agreed toGlossary of professional wrestling terms#TurnturnHeel (professional wrestling)heelin early 1987 to be the counter to the biggest "Face (professional wrestling)babyface" in professional wrestling at that time,Hulk Hogan.cite bookAndré the Giant: A Legendary LifeKrugmanMichael131[[Pocket Books]]2009978-1-4165-4112-7On an edition ofPiper's Pitin 1987, Hogan was presented a trophy for being theWWE World Heavyweight ChampionshipWWF Championfor three years; Andr came out to congratulate him.cite bookAndré the Giant: A Legendary LifeKrugmanMichael132–133[[Pocket Books]]2009978-1-4165-4112-7On the following week'sPiper's Pit, Andr was presented a slightly smaller trophy for being "the only undefeated wrestler in wrestling history." Although Andr had suffered a handful ofProfessional wrestling#CountoutcountoutandProfessional wrestling#Disqualificationdisqualificationlosses in WWF, he had never been pinned or forced to submit in a WWF ring. Hogan came out to congratulate Andr and ended up being the focal point of the interview. Apparently annoyed, Andr walked out in the midst of Hogan's speech.cite bookAndré the Giant: A Legendary LifeKrugmanMichael134–135[[Pocket Books]]2009978-1-4165-4112-7cite webhttp://www.thehistoryofwwe.com/87.htmWWF @ East Rutherford, NJ – Meadowlands – January 5, 1987The History of WWEApril 2, 2011http://web.archive.org/web/20110510061259/http://www.thehistoryofwwe.com/87.htmMay 10, 2011noA discussion between Andr and Hogan was scheduled, and on aPiper's Pitthat aired February 7, 1987, the two met.cite webhttp://www.thehistoryofwwe.com/87.htmWWF @ Tampa, FL – SunDome – January 26, 1987The History of WWEMarch 27, 2011http://web.archive.org/web/20110510061259/http://www.thehistoryofwwe.com/87.htmMay 10, 2011noHogan was introduced first, followed by Andr. Andr was led by longtime rival Bobby Heenan.

Speaking on behalf of his new protg, Heenan accused Hogan of only being Andr's friend so he would not have to defend his title against him. Hogan tried to reason with Andr but his pleas were ignored as he challenged Hogan to a match for the WWF Championship atWrestleMania III. Hogan was still seemingly in disbelief as to what Andr was doing, prompting Heenan to say "You can't believe it, maybe you'll believe this, Hogan" before Andr ripped the T-shirt and crucifix from Hogan, Andr's fingernail scratched Hogan's chest while ripping the shirt off which caused Hogan to bleed.cite bookAndré the Giant: A Legendary LifeKrugmanMichael136–139[[Pocket Books]]2009978-1-4165-4112-7

Following Hogan's acceptance of Andr's challenge on a later edition ofPiper's Pit, the two were part of a 20-man over the top rope battle royal on the March 14 edition ofSaturday Night's Main Event resultsSaturday Night's Main Eventat theJoe Louis ArenainDetroit.cite bookThe History of Professional Wrestling: The Results WWF 1963–1989CawthonGraham623CreateSpace Independent Publishing Platform2013978-1-4928-2597-5Although the battle royal was won byHercules (wrestler)Hercules, Andr claimed to have gained a psychological advantage over Hogan when he threw the WWF Champion over the top rope. The match, which was actually taped on February 21, 1987,aired only two weeks before WrestleMania III to make it seem like Hogan had met his match in Andr the Giant.SNME Battle Royal 1987

At WrestleMania III, he was billed atconvert520lbkgon,cite webhttp://www.wwe.com/shows/wrestlemania/history/wm3/mainevent/WrestleMania III – André the Giant vs. Hulk Hogan – WWE Championship[[WWE]]February 15, 2011and the stress of such immense weight on his bones and joints resulted in constant pain.After recent back surgery, he was also wearing a brace underneath his wrestling singlet.cite bookSex, Lies and Headlocks: The Real Story of Vince McMahon and the World Wrestling Federation[[Crown Publishing Group|Crown Publishers]]AssaelShaunMooneyhamMike71–722002978-0-609-60690-2In front of a record crowd of 93,173 Hogan won the match after body slamming Andr (later dubbed "the bodyslam heard around the world"), followed by Hogan's running leg drop finisher.Years later, Hogan claimed that Andr was so heavy, he felt more likeconvert700lbkgon, and that he actually tore hislatissimus dorsi muscleslamming him.

Another famous myth about the match is that no one, not even WWF ownerVince McMahon, knew until the day of the event if Andr would lose the match. In reality Andr had agreed to lose the match some time before, mostly for health reasons, though he almost pinned Hogan (albeit unintentionally) in the second minute of the match after Hogan tried to slam him but could not hold his weight. Contrary to popular belief, it was not the first time that Hogan had successfully body slammed Andr in a WWF match. A then-heel Hogan slammed a then-face Andr following their match at the "Showdown at Shea" on August 9, 1980, though Andr was much lighter (aroundconvert470lbkgon) and more athletic at the time (Hogan also slammed Andr in a match inHamburg, Pennsylvania, a month later).cite videoHulk Hogan: The Ultimate AnthologyDVD[[WWE]]2006This took place in the territorial days of American wrestling three years before WWF began national expansion, so many of those who watched WrestleMania III had never seen the Giant slammed (Andr had also previously allowedHarley Race,Canek (wrestler)El CanekandStan Hansen, among others, to slam him).cite bookAndré the Giant: A Legendary LifeKrugmanMichael157[[Pocket Books]]2009978-1-4165-4112-7cite bookKing of the Ring: The Harley Race StoryRaceHarleyHarley Race90Sports Publishing L.L.C.2004978-1-58261-818-0

By the time of WrestleMania III, the WWF had gone national, giving more meaning to the AndrHogan match that took place then. The feud between Andr and Hogan simmered during the summer of 1987, as Roussimoff's health declined. The feud began heating up again when wrestlers were named the captains of rival teams at the inauguralSurvivor Series (1987)Survivor Seriesevent. Andr's team won the main event after Andr pinnedBam Bam Bigelow.cite webhttp://www.wwe.com/shows/survivorseries/history/1987/mainevent/Survivor Series 1987 – Main Event[[WWE]]February 15, 2011

In the meantime,Ted DiBiasethe "Million Dollar Man" Ted DiBiasefailed to persuade Hogan to sell him the WWF Championship. After failing to defeat Hogan in a subsequent series of matches, DiBiase turned to Andr to win it for him.cite bookAndré the Giant: A Legendary LifeKrugmanMichael172–175[[Pocket Books]]2009978-1-4165-4112-7Acting as his hired gun, Andr won the WWF title from Hogan (his first singles title) on February 5, 1988 in a match where it was later revealed that appointed refereeDave Hebnerwas "detained backstage", and a replacement (whom Hogan afterwards initially accused of having been paid by DiBiase to get plastic surgery to look like Dave,Hulk Hogan postmatch interview,The Main EventNBC television February 5, 1988but in fact was revealed to have been his evil twin brother,Earl Hebner),"AWWF MagazineInvestigative Report: Dave Hebner's Shadow,"WWE MagazineWWF Magazine, June 1988, p. 30.made a three count on Hogan while his shoulders were off the mat.

After winning, Andr "sold" the title to DiBiase; the transaction was declared invalid by then-Professional wrestling authority figuresWWF presidentJack Tunney and the title was vacated.This was shown on WWF'sNBCprogramWWF The Main EventThe Main Event. AtWrestleMania IV, Andr and Hulk Hogan fought to a double disqualification in a WWF title tournament match (with the idea in the storyline saying that Andr was again working on DiBiase's behalf in giving DiBiase a clearer path in the tournament). Afterward, Andr and Hogan's feud died down after a steel cage match held atWrestleFeston July 31, 1988, in Milwaukee.

At the inaugural SummerSlam pay-per-view held atMadison Square Garden, Andr and DiBiase (billed as the Mega Bucks) faced Hogan and WWF ChampionRandy Savage"Macho Man" Randy Savage(known as the Mega Powers) in the main event, withJesse VenturaJesse "the Body" Venturaas the special guest referee.cite webhttp://www.wwe.com/shows/summerslam/history/1988/mainevent1/SummerSlam 1988 main event match details[[WWE]]March 6, 2011During the match, the Mega Powers' manager,Miss Elizabeth, (Savage's wife Elizabeth Hulette) distracted the Mega Bucks and Ventura when she climbed up on the ring apron, removed her yellow skirt and walked around in a pair of red panties. This allowed Hogan and Savage time to recover and eventually win the match with Hogan pinning DiBiase. Savage forced Ventura's hand down for the final three-count, due to Ventura's character historically being at odds with Hogan, and his unwillingness to count the fall.

Concurrent with the developing feud with the Mega Powers, Andr was placed in a feud withJim Duggan, which began after Duggan knocked out Andr with a two-by-four board during a television taping. Despite Duggan's popularity with fans, Andr regularly got the upper hand in the feud.
article.heading: Feud with Jake "The Snake" Roberts and The Ultimate Warrior (19881989)
article.paragraph: File:Jake Roberts and Andre.jpgthumbAndr feuded withJake Robertsbased on Andr's fear of snakesAndr's next major feud was againstJake Roberts. In this storyline, it was said Andr wasOphidiophobiaafraid of snakes, something Roberts exposed onSaturday Night's Main Eventwhen he threw his snake, Damien, on the frightened Andr; as a result, Andr suffered akayfabemild heart attack and vowed revenge. During the next few weeks, Roberts frequently walked to ringside during Andr's matches, causing him to run from the ring in fright (since he knew what was inside the bag). Throughout their feud (which culminated atWrestleMania V), Roberts constantly used Damien to gain a psychological edge over the much larger and stronger Andr.

In 1989, Andr and the returning Big John Studd briefly reprised their feud, beginning at WrestleMania V, when Studd was the referee in the match with Roberts, this time with Studd as a face and Andr as the heel. During the late summer and fall of 1989, Andr engaged in a brief feud, almost entirely consisting ofhouse shows(non-televised events), with then-WWE Intercontinental ChampionshipIntercontinental ChampionWarrior (wrestler)The Ultimate Warrior. The younger Warrior, WWF's rising star, regularlyGlossary of professional wrestling terms#Squashsquashedthe aging Andr in an attempt to showcase his star quality and promote him as the "next big thing".cite bookAndré the Giant: A Legendary LifeKrugmanMichael297–300[[Pocket Books]]2009978-1-4165-4112-7cite bookHitman: My Real Life in the Cartoon World of WrestlingHartBretBret Hart233[[Hachette Book Group USA#Current imprints|Grand Central Publishing]]2008978-0-446-53972-2
article.heading: The Colossal Connection (19891990)
article.paragraph: In late 1989, Andr was joined with fellowThe Heenan FamilyHeenan FamilymemberTonga FifitaHakuto form a new tag team calledthe Colossal Connection, in part to fill a void left by the departure ofTully BlanchardandArn Anderson(the Brain Busters, who were also members of Heenan's stable) from the WWF, and also to continue to keep the aging Andr in the main event spotlight. The Colossal Connection immediately targeted WWF Tag Team ChampionsDemolition (professional wrestling)Demolition(who had recently won the belts from the Brain Busters). At a television taping on December 13, 1989, the Colossal Connection defeated Demolition to win the titles.Andr and Haku successfully defended their title, mostly against Demolition, untilWrestleMania VIon April 1, 1990, when Demolition took advantage of a mistimed move by the champions to regain the belts.cite webhttp://www.wwe.com/inside/titlehistory/worldtagteam/3044541321241Demolition's third reign[[WWE]]February 15, 2011After the match, a furious Heenan blamed Andr for the title loss and after shouting at him slapped him in the face; an angry Andr responded with a slap of his own that sent Heenan staggering from the ring.cite bookAndré the Giant: A Legendary LifeKrugmanMichael321–322[[Pocket Books]]2009978-1-4165-4112-7Andr also caught Haku's kick attempt, sending him reeling from the ring as well, and prompting support for Andr for the first time since 1987, turning face once again. Due to his ongoing health issues, Andr was not able to wrestle at the time of Wrestlemania VI and Haku actually wrestled the entire match against Demolition without tagging in Andr.
article.heading: Sporadic appearances (19901992)
article.paragraph: Andr continued to make appearances in the WWF throughout 1990 and 1991. He came to the aid ofRay TraylorThe Big Boss Manin hisWrestleMania VIImatch againstCurt HennigMr. Perfect.cite bookAndré the Giant: A Legendary LifeKrugmanMichael326[[Pocket Books]]2009978-1-4165-4112-7

At one point he was advertised to enter the 1991 Royal Rumble, but backed out due to a leg injury.YouTubev-VFCvdFtbcAndr finally returned to action on April 26, 1991, in a six-man tag-team matchup when he teamed with the Rockers in a winning effort against Mr. Fuji and the Orient Express at a house show in Belfast, Northern Ireland.http://www.thehistoryofwwe.com/91.htmOn May 10 he participated in a 17-man battle royal at a house show in Detroit.(won by Kerry Von Erich). His last major WWF storyline following WrestleMania VII had the major heel managers (Bobby Heenan,Sherri MartelSensational Sherri,Slick (wrestling)Slick, andMr. Fuji) trying to recruit Andr one-by-one, only to be turned down in various humiliating ways (e.g. Heenan had his hand crushed, Sherri received a spanking, Slick got locked in the trunk of the car he was offering to Andr and Mr. Fuji got a pie in his face). Finally,Jimmy Hartappeared live onWWF Superstarsto announce that he had successfully signed Andr to tag-team withJohn TentaEarthquake. However, when asked to confirm this byGene Okerlund, Andr denied the claims. This led to Earthquake attacking Andr from behind (injuring his knee).cite webhttp://www.thehistoryofwwe.com/91.htmWWF Show Results 1991March 5, 2011Graham Cawthon(Date: May 6, 1991 Shown: June 1, 1991)Included an in-ring interview by Gene Okerlund in which André the Giant refused Jimmy Hart's offer to become his manager only to have his knee attacked by Earthquake, using Hart's megaphoneJimmy Hart would later get revenge for the humiliation by secretly signingFred OttmanTugboatand formingthe Natural Disasters.cite webhttp://www.thehistoryofwwe.com/91.htmWWF Show Results 1991March 5, 2011Graham Cawthon(Date: May 28, 1991 Shown: June 15, 1991)Earthquake & WWF Tag Team Champions the Nasty Boys (w/ Jimmy Hart) defeated Tugboat & the Bushwhackers at 4:05 when Earthquake pinned Luke with a sit-down splash after Tugboat attacked both of his teammates; after the match, Tugboat embraced with his new friendsThis led to Andr's final major WWF appearance atSummerSlam (1991)SummerSlam'91, where he secondedthe Bushwhackersin their match against the Disasters.cite bookAndré the Giant: A Legendary LifeKrugmanMichael333[[Pocket Books]]2009978-1-4165-4112-7Andr was on crutches at ringside, and after the Disasters won the match they set out to attack Andr, but the Legion of Doom made their way to ringside and got in between them and the Giant, who was preparing to defend himself with one of his crutches. The Disasters left the ringside area as they were outnumbered by the Legion of Doom, the Bushwhackers and Andr, who struck both Earthquake and Typhoon (the former Tugboat) with the crutch as they left. His final WWF appearance came at a house show in Paris, France, on October 9. He was in Davey Boy Smith's corner as the Bulldog faced Earthquake. Davey Boy hit Earthquake with Andr's crutch, allowing Smith to win.

His last U.S. television appearance was in a brief interview onWorld Championship Wrestling's (WCW)Clash of the Champions#Clash of the Champions XX: 20th AnniversaryClash of the Champions XXspecial that aired onTBS (TV channel)TBSon September 2, 1992.cite bookAndré the Giant: A Legendary LifeKrugmanMichael336[[Pocket Books]]2009978-1-4165-4112-7
article.heading: All Japan Pro Wrestling and Universal Wrestling Association (19901992)
article.paragraph: After WrestleMania VI, Andr spent the rest of his in-ring career inAll Japan Pro Wrestling(AJPW) and Mexico'sUniversal Wrestling Association, where he performed under the name "Andr el Gigante." He toured with AJPW three times per year, from 1990 to 1992, usually teaming withGiant Babain tag team matches.cite bookAndré the Giant: A Legendary LifeKrugmanMichael335[[Pocket Books]]2009978-1-4165-4112-7He did his final tour of Mexico in 1992 in a selection of six-man tag matches alongsideBam Bam Bigelowand a variety of Lucha Libre stars facing among othersBad News Allenand future WWF ChampionYokozuna (wrestler)Yokozuna.http://www.cagematch.net/?id=2&nr=926&page=4&year=1992&promotion=68Andr wrestled his final match for AJPW in 1992. After his final match, Andr retired from professional wrestling in the process.
article.heading: Acting career
article.paragraph: Andr branched out into acting again in the 1970s and 1980s, after a 1967 French boxing movie, making his USA acting debut playing a Sasquatch ("Bigfoot") on the 1970s television seriesThe Six Million Dollar Man.cite bookAndré the Giant: A Legendary LifeKrugmanMichael18–19[[Pocket Books]]2009978-1-4165-4112-7He appeared in other television shows, includingThe Greatest American Hero,B. J. and the Bear,The Fall Guyand 1990'sZorro (1990 TV series)Zorro.cite webhttp://www.imdb.com/title/tt0755189/"Zorro" Big Brother (TV episode 1991)IMDbFebruary 16, 2011

Towards the end of his career, Andr starred in several films. He had an uncredited appearance in the 1984 filmConan the Destroyeras Dagoth,cite bookAndré the Giant: A Legendary LifeKrugmanMichael79[[Pocket Books]]2009978-1-4165-4112-7cite webhttp://www.imdb.com/title/tt0087078/fullcredits#castFull cast and crew for Conan the DestroyerIMDbthe resurrected horned giant god who is killed by Conan (Arnold Schwarzenegger). That same year, Andr also made an appearance inMicki & Maude(billed as Andr Rousimmoff).cite webhttp://www.imdb.com/title/tt0087718/fullcredits#castFull cast and crew for Micki + MaudeIMDbHe appeared most notably as Fezzik, his own favorite role,in the 1987 filmThe Princess Bride (film)The Princess Bride. Both the film and Andr's performance retain a devoted following.

In his last film, he appeared in a cameo role as a circus giant in the comedyTrading Mom, which was released a year after his death.cite webhttp://us.imdb.com/title/tt0111470/http://web.archive.org/web/20070213084344/http://us.imdb.com/title/tt0111470/February 13, 2007''Trading Mom'' (IMDB)August 15, 2008

article.heading: Personal life
article.paragraph: Roussimoff had one daughter, Robin Christensen Roussimoff, who was born in 1979.

Andr was mentioned in the1974Guinness World RecordsGuinness Book of World Recordsas the highest-paid wrestler in history at that time. He had earned US $400,000 in one year during the early 1970s.cite bookAndré the Giant: A Legendary LifeKrugmanMichael18[[Pocket Books]]2009978-1-4165-4112-7

Roussimoff has been unofficially crowned "the greatest drunk on Earth"cite bookAndré the Giant: A Legendary LifeKrugmanMichael123[[Pocket Books]]2009978-1-4165-4112-7for once consuming 119convert12USflozonbeers (over 41 litres) in six hours.cite webhttp://madconomist.com/5-coolest-beer-records5 Coolest Beer RecordsMadConomistDavydovDmitriMay 20, 2008April 1, 2011On an episode of WWE'sLegends of Wrestling,Mike Graham (wrestler)Mike Grahamsaid Andr once drank 156convert16USflozmlonbeers in one sitting, which was confirmed byDusty Rhodes (wrestler)Dusty Rhodes.The Fabulous Moolahwrote in her autobiography that Andr drank 127 beers in aPittsburgh, Pennsylvania, hotel bar and later passed out in the lobby. The staff could not move him and had to leave him there until he awoke.cite bookEllisonLillianThe Fabulous MoolahThe Fabulous Moolah: First Goddess of the Squared Circle2003978-0-06-001258-8ReaganBooks160

Anurban legendexists surrounding Andr's 1987 surgery in which his size made it impossible for theanesthesiologistto estimate a dosage via standard methods; consequently, his alcohol tolerance was used as a guideline instead.True stories from the fake world of wrestling, by David Shoemaker, at theNew York Post; published October 27, 2013; retrieved March 27, 2014

Andr was arrested by theLinn County, Iowa, sheriff in 1989 and charged with assault after he allegedly roughed up a local television cameraman.Wayback20080530034919http://www.thesmokinggun.com/mugshots/andregiantmug1.htmlThe Smoking Gun.cite bookAndré the Giant: A Legendary LifeKrugmanMichael300[[Pocket Books]]2009978-1-4165-4112-7

William Goldman, the author of the novel and the screenplay ofThe Princess Bride, wrote in his nonfiction workWhich Lie Did I Tell?that Andr was one of the gentlest and most generous people he ever knew. Whenever Andr ate with someone in a restaurant he would pay, but he would also insist on paying when he was a guest. After one meal,Arnold Schwarzeneggerhad quietly moved to the cashier to pay before Andr could, but then found himself being physically lifted, carried from his table, and deposited on top of his car by Andr andWilt Chamberlain.cite webhttp://uproxx.com/videos/2012/09/arnold-schwarzeneggers-dinner-wilt-chamberlain-andre-giant/Arnold Schwarzenegger’s Dinner With Wilt Chamberlain and Andre the GiantSeptember 10, 2014
article.heading: Death
article.paragraph: Roussimoff died in his sleep ofHeart failurecongestive heart failureon the night of January 27, 1993, in a Paris hotel room.cite bookAndré the Giant: A Legendary LifeKrugmanMichael337[[Pocket Books]]2009978-1-4165-4112-7He was in Paris to attend his father's funeral.Andre the Giant, 46, Professional Wrestler (Obituary)New York Times, January 31, 1993.His body wascrematedaccording to his wishes and his ashes were scattered at his ranch inEllerbe, North Carolina.cite webhttp://www.wral.com/news/local/video/4797970/WRAL News, Raleigh, NCWral.comJune 8, 2012
article.heading: Legacy

link.target: File:Big Show with Andre the Giant trophy.jpg
link.part: Big Show- a wrestler often compared with Andr due to his size - was the winner of the 2015 Andr the Giant Memorial Battle Royal atWrestleMania 31, and is posing alongside the Andr the Giant Memorial Trophy, which goes to the winner of the annual match.

list.listitem: In 1993 when the then-World Wrestling Federation created theWWE Hall of FameWWF Hall of Fame, Andr the Giant was the inaugural inductee(and the only 1993 inductee)
Andr was the inspiration for the1998 in film1998 filmMy Giant, written by his friendBilly Crystal, whom he had met during the filming ofThe Princess Bride.

Paul Wight, better known as theBig Show, is more similar in body structure to Andr than any other wrestler since Andr's death. He was originally billed as the son of Andr during his stint in WCW (when he was known as simply "the Giant") despite no biological relation.cite bookAndré the Giant: A Legendary LifeKrugmanMichael341–342[[Pocket Books]]2009978-1-4165-4112-7While also suffering from acromegaly, unlike Andr, Wight did get surgery on hispituitary glandin the early 1990s, which successfully halted the progress of his condition. The former wrestlerJorge Gonzlez (wrestler)Giant Gonzlezsuffered from problems similar to those that Andr had near the end of his life and died in 2010 due toDiabetes mellitusdiabetescomplications.

In 1999, Andr was the subject of an episode ofBiography (TV series)A&E Biography, titledAndr the Giant: Larger Than Life. The documentary covered Andr's childhood and early life in France, as well as the beginning of his wrestling career, his struggles with acromegaly, his personal life, and his final years. Andr's brother, Jacques Roussimoff, was interviewed for the documentary, as were fellow wrestling personalitiesGorilla Monsoon,Tim White (wrestling)Tim White,Arnold Skaaland,Vince McMahon,Freddie Blassie,Killer Kowalski,Rene Goulet, and Frenchy Bernard, as well as wrestling historian Sheldon Goldberg. Several of Andr's longtime hometown friends were interviewed as well. The documentary described Andr as pro wrestling's "first and only international attraction" and that "on his broad shoulders, wrestling rose from its status as a questionable sport to become big business, and some might argue, performance art."

TheAndre the Giant Has a PosseObeybrand icon originated from wheatpaste posters that artistShepard Faireycreated based upon a photo of Andr the Giant that he had found in a newspaper.cite webhttp://legacy.utsandiego.com/news/features/20071230-9999-mz1a30art.htmlSocial ferment not always reflected in fermentation of artworksRobert L.PincusJune 22, 2012

Capcom's video game characterList of Street Fighter characters#HugoHugo, from theStreet Fighter (series)''Street Fighter''series (known asList of Street Fighter characters#HugoAndorein theFinal Fight (series)''Final Fight''series) is based on him.

Andr has made appearances as himself in video games for years, as early as 1989'sWWF Superstars, where he appears as a non-playableBoss (video gaming)game bossalong with Ted DiBiase, fighting as their real-life tag team the Mega Bucks, he is also playable inWWF No Mercy,WWE 2K14, released in 2013, where he appears as one of many playable "legend" characters, andWWE 2K15, as part of thePath of theThe Ultimate WarriorWarriorDLC. He also appears inWWE Day of Reckoning,WWE SmackDown! vs. RAW,WWE SmackDown! vs. RAW 2006,andWWE All Starsas a playable "legend" character.

On January 25, 2005, WWE releasedAndr The Giant, aDVDfocusing on the life and career of Andre.cite webhttp://www.amazon.com/dp/B00079I0BUWWE – Andre the GiantAmazon.comFebruary 15, 2011The DVD is a reissue of the out-of-printAndr The GiantVHSmade byWWE Home VideoColiseum Videoin 1985, with commentary byMichael Cole (wrestling)Michael ColeandTazzreplacing Gorilla Monsoon and Jesse Ventura's commentary on his WrestleMania match with Big John Studd. The video is hosted byAlfred Hayes (wrestler)Lord Alfred Hayes. Later matches, including Andr's battles against Hulk Hogan while a heel, are not included on this DVD.

The 2014 graphic novelAndr The Giant: The Life and The Legend(First Second Books), written and drawn byBox Brown, tells the story of Andr's life and career. Research for the book included interviews with Andr's fellow wrestlers and actors such asChristopher Guest,Mandy Patinkinand others.

On the March 10, 2014, episode ofWWE RawRaw,WrestleMania XXXhost Hulk Hogan announced that in honor of Andr's legacy, he was establishing the Andr the Giant Memorial Battle Royal, that would take place at the event, with the winner receiving the Andr the Giant Memorial Trophy (made in the likeness of Andr).3-10-14 Raw results - WWE.comOn April 6, 2014, at WrestleMania XXX,Antonio CesaroCesarowon the match after eliminating Big Show using a body slam similar to the body slam Hulk Hogan used on Andr at WrestleMania III.WrstleMania results - Wrestle Zone.comAtWrestleMania 31, the second annual Andr the Giant Memorial Battle Royal took place at Levi's Stadium, establishing the match as a yearly tradition at WWE's marquee event.
